summary: This document is an email chain from February 10, 2020, between FBI personnel regarding a request to decrypt a plist file from an iPad backup related to the Epstein case (31E-NY-3027571). The emails discuss password attempts and the status of the decryption request submitted in September 2019.

persons.name: Irving
persons.context: Mentioned as one of two passwords (along with 'Konigsberg') that were recovered in a previous Filevault2 case in September 2019 and suggested for trying on the current plist file.

persons.name: Konigsberg
persons.context: Mentioned as one of two passwords (along with 'Irving') that were recovered in a previous Filevault2 case in September 2019 and suggested for trying on the current plist file.

events.title: Previous Filevault2 decryption case
events.description: A prior case where the FBI's Secure Technologies Exploitation Unit recovered passwords 'Irving' and 'Konigsberg' for the requester.

events.title: Initial plist submission for Epstein case
events.description: An iPad backup plist from the Epstein case (31E-NY-3027571) was submitted for decryption through an automated FBI site.

keyFacts: The FBI was actively working on decrypting an iPad backup (plist file) from the Epstein investigation as of February 2020.
The decryption request for case 31E-NY-3027571 was initially submitted in September 2019 and was still pending as of February 2020.
Two previously recovered passwords, 'Irving' and 'Konigsberg', were suggested for use in the decryption attempt.
The correspondence highlights the FBI's internal technical efforts and collaboration (CART, Secure Technologies Exploitation Unit) to access encrypted evidence.
The document is subject to a protective order restricting certain paragraphs.
